What if I started this review telling you how I liked the main characters in this movie. How they were likable and easy on the eyes.
But then jumped to the Gabriel House in Jacksonville, and how it was created by the real-life Jorge Bacardi after he received life-saving surgery?
You'd probably get annoyed because you'd wonder what one story has to do with the other. 
2 HEARTS is a lot like that: 2 seemingly unrelated stories that jump back and forth without any reason as to why they're connected. Is she the daughter of Jorge who's now in college? Is he the illegitimate son of the Bacardi fortune. Did they get killed by Jorge's limo?
The ending will probably cause lots of tears... that is if you get to it. And it's there that you'll learn why the writers & director are telling you these vacuous romantic tales. 
For me, the ends didn't justify the means. This is poor storytelling with underdeveloped characters, no goals/motivations/desires explored and I'll be d@mned if I could ever find a theme because, well, the characters have no arc. 
I don't know if the story is more powerful if you know the real true story behind the movie's inspiration. I didn't until the end and I still find this story unsatisfying. Just because it's base on a true story doesn't mean that you can be boring. Not really worth your time.

This movie appears in its beginnings to be a lightweight nearly Hallmark style romcom, until it takes a serious turn in its final third, and this third act redeems the project. And at its conclusion, it makes a compelling and useful statement. The directing and script are is choppy but the movie has, per its title, plenty of heart.

Quando anche una storia vera non basta a rendere un film guardabile.
Interpretazioni veramente scadenti ed esagerate in ogni espressione, aiutate nel disastro da una regia che crea qualcosa di molto vicino ad una soap opera anni '90.
Anche la sceneggiatura è piena di banalità e di luoghi comuni, la costruzione dei personaggi tende a renderli piuttosto antipatici; specialmente il giovane protagonista.
Ultimo ma non meno importante, il doppio finale è un trucco utilizzato troppe volte, la maggior parte delle quali a sproposito; questa è una di quelle.
Alcune sequenze sono veramente imbarazzanti.
